Where the creditor agreed by pactum de non petendo not to sue one of two or more correi debendi, the other or rest could take advantage of the pactum only if, as it is said, it was in rem (see on Bk. iv. 14. 4 inf.), even though partners os the other, Dig. 2. 14. 25. 1, ‘ multum enim interest, utrum res ipsa solvatur, an persona liberetur’ Dig. 45. 2. 19, ‘in rem pacta omnibus prosunt, quorum obligationem dissolutam esse eiuS, qui paciscebatur, interfuit' Dig. 2. 14. 25. 5. Hence the pactum de non petendo in rem of one correus debendi benefits the rest whenever on payment by one of them he would have regressus against the otherS, sor otherwise the pactum would be practically inoperative. But if, conversely, one of two or more eorreal creditors concluded a pactum de non petendo with their J'oint debtor, the latter could in no case plead it in defence to an action instituted by the other or others: ‘ si unus ex argentariis sociis cum debitore pactus sit, an etiam alteri noceat exceptio?
